differences.concept_a_point: Retains magnetic properties even without the influence of an external magnetic field
differences.concept_b_point: Behaves as magnet only in the presence of a strong magnetic field

differences.concept_a_point: Usually made of hard materials
differences.concept_b_point: Usually made of soft materials

differences.concept_a_point: Cannot be switched on or off; magnetism is permanent
differences.concept_b_point: Can be controlled by switching current on or off

differences.concept_a_point:
1. Bar magnet (used in compass)
2. Horse-shoe magnet (used in motors)
differences.concept_b_point:
1. Electromagnet in electric bell
2. Electromagnet in crane for lifting iron

differences.concept_a_point: Temporary magnet - retains magnetism only when current flows
differences.concept_b_point: Permanent magnet - retains magnetism without any external source

differences.concept_a_point: Made with soft iron core (soft material)
differences.concept_b_point: Made of hard materials like steel or alnico

differences.concept_a_point: Strength can be increased by increasing current or number of turns
differences.concept_b_point: Strength is fixed and cannot be easily changed

differences.concept_a_point:
1. Electromagnet in electric bell
2. Electromagnet in MRI machine
differences.concept_b_point:
1. Fridge magnet
2. Compass needle

differences.concept_a_point: Insulated copper wire wrapped around a bar-shaped soft iron core
differences.concept_b_point: Insulated copper wire wrapped around a U-shaped soft iron core

differences.concept_a_point: North and south poles at the two opposite ends of the bar
differences.concept_b_point: North and south poles at the two open ends of the U-shape

differences.concept_a_point: Magnetic field is spread out at the ends
differences.concept_b_point: Both poles are close together giving stronger combined field

differences.concept_a_point:
1. Electromagnet in simple circuits
2. Solenoid in doorbell transformer
differences.concept_b_point:
1. Electromagnet in electric bell
2. Electromagnet in magnetic separators

differences.concept_a_point: Gets magnetized easily when placed in a magnetic field
differences.concept_b_point: More difficult to magnetize

differences.concept_a_point: Loses magnetism quickly when magnetic field is removed
differences.concept_b_point: Retains magnetism for a long time even without external field

differences.concept_a_point: Used as core for temporary magnets like electromagnets
differences.concept_b_point: Used for making permanent magnets

differences.concept_a_point:
1. Soft iron core in transformer
2. Soft iron core in electric bell
differences.concept_b_point:
1. Steel bar magnet
2. Alnico magnet in loudspeaker

differences.concept_a_point: When electric current flows through a conductor, it produces a magnetic field around it
differences.concept_b_point: The phenomenon of producing electric current by changing magnetic lines of force

differences.concept_a_point: Requires electric current to flow
differences.concept_b_point: Requires change in magnetic lines of force

differences.concept_a_point: Magnetic field is produced from electric current
differences.concept_b_point: Induced current is produced from changing magnetic field

differences.concept_a_point:
1. Electromagnet producing magnetic field
2. Current in wire deflecting compass needle
differences.concept_b_point:
1. Moving magnet near coil produces current
2. Generator producing electricity

differences.concept_a_point: The end acts as SOUTH pole
differences.concept_b_point: The end acts as NORTH pole

differences.concept_a_point: Clockwise = South (both have 'S' sound)
differences.concept_b_point: Anticlockwise = North

differences.concept_a_point: Field lines enter at this end
differences.concept_b_point: Field lines emerge from this end

differences.concept_a_point:
1. South pole of solenoid when viewed from front
2. Entry point of field lines in bar magnet
differences.concept_b_point:
1. North pole of solenoid when viewed from front
2. Exit point of field lines in bar magnet

differences.concept_a_point: Converts mechanical energy to electrical energy
differences.concept_b_point: Converts electrical energy to mechanical energy

differences.concept_a_point: Works on electromagnetic induction
differences.concept_b_point: Works on magnetic effect of current

differences.concept_a_point: Receives rotation (mechanical), produces electricity
differences.concept_b_point: Receives electricity, produces rotation (mechanical)

differences.concept_a_point:
1. Power plant generator
2. Bicycle dynamo for headlight
differences.concept_b_point:
1. Ceiling fan motor
2. Electric car motor

differences.concept_a_point: Flows in one direction only
differences.concept_b_point: Continuously changes direction periodically

differences.concept_a_point: Creates constant magnetic field
differences.concept_b_point: Creates continuously changing magnetic field

differences.concept_a_point: Cannot work with transformers
differences.concept_b_point: Required for transformers to work

differences.concept_a_point:
1. Current from dry cell battery
2. Current from car battery
differences.concept_b_point:
1. Current from wall socket at home
2. Current from power generators

differences.concept_a_point: Highly sensitive - can detect very small currents
differences.concept_b_point: Less sensitive - designed for larger currents

differences.concept_a_point: Used to detect presence and direction of current
differences.concept_b_point: Used to measure the magnitude of current

differences.concept_a_point: Preferred for detecting small induced currents
differences.concept_b_point: May not show deflection for small induced currents

differences.concept_a_point:
1. Galvanometer in electromagnetic induction experiment
2. Galvanometer in physics lab circuits
differences.concept_b_point:
1. Ammeter in home circuit panel
2. Ammeter in car dashboard

differences.concept_a_point: Cannot retain magnetism after magnetizing force is removed
differences.concept_b_point: Retains magnetism even after magnetizing force is removed

differences.concept_a_point: Easy to magnetize
differences.concept_b_point: Difficult to magnetize but stays magnetized longer

differences.concept_a_point: Used for making temporary magnets (electromagnets)
differences.concept_b_point: Used for making permanent magnets

differences.concept_a_point:
1. Soft iron in transformer core
2. Soft iron in electromagnet core
differences.concept_b_point:
1. Steel in bar magnets
2. Alnico in loudspeaker magnets

differences.concept_a_point: Producing electric current from changing magnetic field
differences.concept_b_point: Branch of physics dealing with magnetic effect of electric current

differences.concept_a_point: Magnetism produces electricity
differences.concept_b_point: Electricity produces magnetism

differences.concept_a_point: Requires changing magnetic field and a conductor
differences.concept_b_point: Requires electric current flowing through conductor

differences.concept_a_point:
1. Generator producing electricity
2. Transformer transferring power
differences.concept_b_point:
1. Electromagnet lifting iron scraps
2. Electric bell using electromagnet

differences.concept_a_point: Circuit is complete - current flows through
differences.concept_b_point: Circuit is broken - current cannot flow

differences.concept_a_point: Armature touches contact screw
differences.concept_b_point: Armature moves away from contact screw

differences.concept_a_point: Electromagnet gets magnetized
differences.concept_b_point: Electromagnet loses magnetism

differences.concept_a_point:
1. Light switch in ON position
2. Contact screw touching armature in bell
differences.concept_b_point:
1. Light switch in OFF position
2. Armature pulled away from contact screw

questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet
